content:
A monad (M^,η^,μ^)(\widehat{M},\widehat{\eta},\widehat{\mu})(M,η​,μ​) on D\mathbf{D}D is called a lifting of monad (M,η,μ)(M,\eta,\mu)(M,η,μ) on C\mathbf{C}C along U:D→CU: \mathbf{D} \to \mathbf{C}U:D→C if the following three equations hold:

UM^=MUUη^=ηUUμ^=μUU\widehat{M} = MU \quad U\widehat{\eta} = \eta U \quad U\widehat{\mu} = \mu UUM=MUUη​=ηUUμ​=μU

Given a monad M^\widehat{M}M that lifts MMM along UUU, a monad T^\widehat{T}T on D\mathbf{D}D and a monad isomorphism ρ^:M^≅T^\widehat{\rho}: \widehat{M} \cong \widehat{T}ρ​:M≅T. Can I find a monad TTT on C\mathbf{C}C such that T^\widehat{T}T lifts TTT and moreover there is an isomorphism ρ:M≅T\rho: M \cong Tρ:M≅T? (optionally it satisfies Uρ^=ρUU\widehat{\rho} = \rho UUρ​=ρU). I summarized this situation in the picture below.
image.png

I don't believe this is true with no assumption on UUU because I don't even know how to construct the functor TTT. If UUU has a left adjoint FFF, then I can define

T=C→FD→T^D→UC.T = \mathbf{C} \xrightarrow{F} \mathbf{D} \xrightarrow{\widehat{T}} \mathbf{D} \xrightarrow{U} \mathbf{C}.T=CF​DT​DU​C.

I am stuck here because I don't even know how to show T^\widehat{T}T is a functor lifting of TTT. However, the possibility that it is not a monad lifting breaks my mind, because it feels like functoriality or naturality of some stuff would fail in some way. Yet, I cannot prove how this does not work...

Right, that's not true with no assumptions on UUU. Your proposed T=UT^FT = U\hat{T}FT=UT^F doesn't work either in general, because you have TU=UT^FUTU = U\hat{T}FUTU=UT^FU which can't be expected to equal UT^U\hat{T}UT^ unless FU=IdFU=\rm IdFU=Id.
If you want to work in an isomorphism-invariant way, you can either talk about liftings up to isomorphism, or take D\mathbf{D}D to be a [[displayed category]] over C\mathbf{C}C.

Mike Shulman said:

Right, that's not true with no assumptions on UUU. Your proposed T=UT^FT = U\hat{T}FT=UT^F doesn't work either in general, because you have TU=UT^FUTU = U\hat{T}FUTU=UT^FU which can't be expected to equal UT^U\hat{T}UT^ unless FU=IdFU=\rm IdFU=Id.

Exactly, but I am not able to think of an example because if TU≠UT^TU \neq U\widehat{T}TU=UT it feels like the isomorphism ρ^\widehat{\rho}ρ​ has to make some weird choices of bijections that would not make it natural.

Mike Shulman said:

If you want to work in an isomorphism-invariant way, you can either talk about liftings up to isomorphism, or take D\mathbf{D}D to be a [[displayed category]] over C\mathbf{C}C.

Thanks! I think that would probably work in my case, but unfortunately I want to work with monad liftings for Applications™. I guess this will just make my theorems a bit uglier.

Here's an easy way to see that it's not possible in general. Suppose there are two objects d,d′∈Dd,d'\in \mathbf{D}d,d′∈D such that Ud=Ud′=cUd = Ud' = cUd=Ud′=c, say. Then UM^d=UM^d′U\hat{M}d = U\hat{M}d'UM^d=UM^d′ since both equal McMcMc. But we can choose T^\hat{T}T^ in such a way that UT^d≠UT^d′U\hat{T}d \neq U\hat{T}d'UT^d=UT^d′, which implies there cannot be a TTT that is lifted by T^\hat{T}T^ since otherwise UT^dU\hat{T} dUT^d and UT^d′U\hat{T}d'UT^d′ would both equal TcTcTc.
And we can do that even if UUU has a left adjoint.

It is this "we can choose" that makes me not totally convinced. Because after choosing that, we also need to choose ρ^d\widehat{\rho}_dρ​d​ and ρ^d′\widehat{\rho}_{d'}ρ​d′​, and then you need to check that is compatible with possible morphisms between ddd and d′d'd′.

It's easy to modify any functor by isomorphisms to a naturally isomorphic one. If F:A→BF:A\to BF:A→B is any functor and you choose for every a∈Aa\in Aa∈A an object Ga∈BGa\in BGa∈B and an isomorphism αa:Fa≅Ga\alpha_a : Fa \cong Gaαa​:Fa≅Ga, this choice of GGG on objects extends uniquely to a functor G:A→BG:A\to BG:A→B such that α\alphaα is a natural transformation. For f:x→yf:x\to yf:x→y in AAA, define Gf=αy∘Ff∘αx−1Gf = \alpha_y \circ Ff \circ \alpha_x^{-1}Gf=αy​∘Ff∘αx−1​, and then the naturality squares hold by definition.

So in this case, given the functor M^\hat{M}M^, we just need to choose some object T^d\hat{T}dT^d such that UT^d≠UM^dU\hat{T}d\neq U\hat{M} dUT^d=UM^d, and an isomorphism M^d≅T^d\hat{M}d \cong \hat{T}dM^d≅T^d, and set T^x=M^x\hat{T} x = \hat{M} xT^x=M^x for all x≠dx\neq dx=d. Then this makes T^\hat{T}T^ a functor isomorphic to M^\hat{M}M^, and we can transport the monad structure across that isomorphism.
Ah, thanks a lot. I am going to sleep better :smile:
